_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary 

Executive Summary for MidAmerican Energy Company?s Greater Des Moines Energy Center Risk Management Plan 

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies (40 CFR 68.155(a))

MidAmerican Energy Company?s (MidAmerican) Greater Des Moines Energy Center is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. The commitment is demonstrated by an accidental release program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with processes at the facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent potential releases of regulated substances.

 The Facility and Regulated Processes (40 CFR 68.155(b))

At the time of development of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) under the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68, 

MidAmerican Energy Company had not begun to operate in combined cycle mode.  Therefore, the use of the regulated process (aqueous ammonia storage tank) had not been started.

MidAmerican Energy Company?s primary activity is the generation of electrical energy by combustion of natural gas. 

Part of that activity involves the use of a system that provides aqueous ammonia for selective catalytic reduction in the heat recovery steam generators. The aqueous ammonia storage and forwarding system (the process) consists of a storage tank two forwarding pumps, associated piping, valves, and instrumentation.  Atomized ammonia is sprayed on to the SCR section. The flue gas entrains the ammonia and as the mixture passes through the SCR, it undergoes a reaction that reduces nitrogen oxides to meet the standards within the facility?s air permit.



The maximum inventory of aqueous ammonia in the process is 25,000 gallons (187,220 pounds). In the storage tank, ammonia is concentrated at 29.4% in water. 



Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios (40 CFR 68.165(a)(1))

To perform the required off-site consequence analysis for the facility, MidAmerican use

d the EPA's Risk Management Program RMP*Comp, Version 1.07. The worst-case scenario involved the catastrophic release of aqueous ammonia from the storage tank. In this scenario, all 25,000 gallons of aqueous ammonia is released into the diked enclosure around the storage tank, forming a pool from which evaporation takes place. At Class F atmospheric stability and 1.5 meters/second wind speed, the maximum distance of 0.10 mile is obtained to a toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L. 

The alternative release scenario is one more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario, unless no release occurs. In this scenario, 25,000 gallons of aqueous ammonia is released from the storage tank into the diked enclosure, No controls were assumed, even though row valves may be utilized in an emergency to mitigate releases. Also, less than 25,000 gallons of aqueous ammonia will be typically present. Under neutral weather conditions (stability Class D) and wind speed of 3 meters/second, the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L is<0.10 miles. 

We determined that there are no public receptors within the worst-case or alternative release scenarios.  Also, since the facility is new, there is no history of releases of regulated substances. Therefore, this process qualifies for Program Level 1. The Greater Des Moines Energy Center?s responsibility under Program Level 1 is as follows:



* Submit a single RMP, as provided in ?68.150 to 68.185. The RMP shall include a registration that reflects all covered processes.

* Analyze the worst-case release scenario for the process, as provided in ?68.25; document that the nearest public receptor is beyond the distance to a toxic or flammable endpoint defined in ?68.22(a); and submit in the RMP the worst-case release scenario as provided in ?68.165;

* Complete the five-year accident history for the process as provided in ?68.42 of this part and submit it in the RMP as provided in ?68.168;

* Ensure that response actions have been coordinate

here is no history of accidents at the Greater Des Moines Energy Center. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Prior to the aqueous ammonia being brought onsite, the Greater Des Moines Energy Center will install ammonia monitors around the aqueous ammonia storage tank.
